channel.title: AWS Cloud Practitioners on
channel.description: Recent content in AWS Cloud Practitioners on

item.title: 0-1 Exam Details
item.description: Duration of 1.5 hours So you get ~1.5mins per question Exam time is 90 mins Seat time is 120 mins

item.title: 00-01 Exam Details
item.description: Duration of 1.5 hours So you get ~1.5mins per question Exam time is 90 mins Seat time is 120 mins

item.title: 01-01 Evolution of Cloud Hosting
item.description: Dedicated Server One physical machine dedicated to a single business. Runs a single web-app/site. Very Expensive, High Maintenance, *High Security

item.title: 01-02 Cloud Service Provider CSP
item.description: A Cloud Service Provider (CSP) is a company which provides Cloud services: which offer many products e.g. tens to hundreds of services that can be chained together to create cloud architectures that are accessible via Single Unified API eg.

item.title: 01-03 Landscape of CSPs
item.description: Tier-1 (Top Tier) Early to market, wide offering, strong synergies between services, well recognized in the industry Amazon Web Services (AWS) Microsoft Azure Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Alibaba Cloud Tier-2 (Mid Tier) Backed by well-known tech companies, slow to innovate and turned to specialization

item.title: 01-04 Gartner Magic Quadrant
item.description: Gartner Magic Quadrant (MQ) is a series of market research reports published by IT consulting firm Gartner that rely on proprietary qualitative data analysis methods to demonstrate market trends, such as direction, maturity, and participants.

item.title: 01-05 Common Cloud Services
item.description: A cloud service can have hundreds of cloud services that are grouped into various types of services. The four most common types for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) would be:

item.title: 01-06 The Evolution of Computing
item.description: Dedicated A physical server wholly utilized by a single customer. Must guess capacity. Overpay for an underutilized service. Can’t vertical scale, need a manual migration.

item.title: 01-07 Types of Cloud Computing
item.description: Software as a Service For Customers A product that is run and managed by the service provider Users don’t worry about how the service is maintained.

item.title: 01-08 Cloud Computing Deployment Models
item.description: Public Cloud Everything (the workload or project) is built on the CSP Aka Cloud-Native or Cloud First Private Cloud Everything built on company’s data centers Also known as On-Premise The cloud could be OpenStack Hybrid Cloud Using both an both an On-Premise and Cloud Service Provider (CSP) Cross Cloud Using Multiple Cloud Providers [!

item.title: 01-09 Deployment Model Use Cases
item.description: Cloud Fully Utilizing Cloud Computing Companies that are starting out today, or are small enough to make the leap from VPS to a CSP.

item.title: 02-01 Six Advantages of Cloud
item.description: Pay-as-you-go pricing trade capital expense for variable expense Benefit from massive economies of scale Amazon has already spent the high upfront cost to build data centers.

item.title: 03-01 Global Infrastructure
item.description: Regions Regions are ==geographically distinct locations== consisting of one more Availability Zones (AV). [!tip]+ Key Facts US-EAST-1 (North Virginia) was the first region

item.title: 03-02 Availability Zone
item.description: An Availability Zone (AV) is a physical location made up of one or more data centers. A ==datacenter== is a secured building that contains hundreds of thousands of computers.

item.title: 03-03 Fault Tolerance
item.description: A ==Fault Domain== is a section of a network that is vulnerable to damage if a critical device or system fails.

item.title: 03-04 Point of Presence PoP
item.description: ==Points of Presence (PoP)== is an intermediate location between an AWS Region and the end user, and this location could be a datacenter owned by AWS or a trusted partner that is utilized by AWS Services related for content delivery or expedited upload.

item.title: 03-05 Direct Connect
item.description: AWS Direct Connect is a private/dedicated connection between your datacenter, office, co-location and AWS. #aws-service ^1d5a3b Direct Connect has two very-fast network connection options:

item.title: 03-06 Local Zones
item.description: Local Zones are data-centers located very close to a densely populated area to provide single-digit millisecond low latency performance (eg.

item.title: 03-07 Wavelength Zones
item.description: AWS Wavelength Zones allows for edge-computing on 5G Networks. Applications will have ultra-low latency being as close as possible to the users.

item.title: 03-08 Data Residency
item.description: What is data residency The physical or geographic location of where an organization or cloud resources reside. What is Compliance Boundaries?

item.title: 03-09 AWS in China
item.description: AWS China is completely isolate intentionally from AWS Global to meet regulatory compliance for Mainland China. AWS China is on its own domain at: amazonaws.

item.title: 03-10 Ground Station
item.description: AWS Ground Station is a fully managed service that lets you control satellite communications, process data, and scale your operations without having to worry about building or managing your own ground station infrastructure.

item.title: 03-11 Outposts
item.description: AWS Outposts is a fully managed service that offers the same AWS infrastructure, AWS services, APIs, and tools to virtually any datacenter, co-location space, or on-premises facility for a truly consistent hybrid experience.

item.title: 04-01 Cloud Architecture Terminologies
item.description: What is a Solutions Architect? A role in a technical organization that architects a technical solution using multiple systems via researching, documentation, experimentation.

item.title: 04-02 High Availability
item.description: Your ability for your service to remain available by ensuring there is *no single point of failure and/or ensure a certain level of performance

item.title: 04-03 High Scalability
item.description: Your ability to increase your capacity based on the increasing demand of traffic, memory and computing power Vertical Scaling Upgrade to a bigger server Horizontal Scaling Add more servers of the same size

item.title: 04-04 High Elasticity
item.description: Your ability to automatically increase or decrease your capacity based on the current demand of traffic, memory and computing power

item.title: 04-05 Highly Fault Tolerant
item.description: Your ability for your service to ensure there is ==no single point of failure.== Preventing the chance of failure. Fail-overs are when you have a plan to shift traffic to a redundant system in case the primary system fails.

item.title: 04-06 High Durability
item.description: Your ability to recover from a disaster and to prevent the loss of data solutions that recover from a disaster is known as ==Disaster Recovery (DR)==.

item.title: 04-07 Business Continuity Plan
item.description: A business continuity plan (BCP) is a document that outlines how a business will continue operating during an unplanned disruption in services.

item.title: 04-08 Disaster Recovery Options
item.description: There are multiple options for recovery that trade cost vs time to recover. Backup & Restore Pilot Light Warm Standby Multi-site Active/active RPO/RTO ~ Hours RPO/RTO ~ 10mins RPO/RTO ~ minutes RPO/RTO ~ Real-time You backup your data and restore it to new infrastructure Data is replicated to another region with minimal services running Scaled down copy of your infrastructure running ready to scale up Scaled up copy of your infrastructure in another region • Lower priority use cases • less stringent rpo • business critical services • zero downtime • Restore data after event • core services • scale resources after event • near zero loss • deploy resources after event • start & scale resources after event • cost $$$ • mission critical services • cost $ • cost $$ • • cost $$$$

item.title: 04-09 Recovery Time Objective RTO
item.description: Recovery Time Objective (RTO) is the maximum acceptable delay between the interruption of service and restoration of service. This objective determines what is considered an acceptable time window when service is unavailable and is defined by the organization.

item.title: 04-10 Recovery Point Objective RPO
item.description: Recovery Point Objective (RPO) is the maximum acceptable amount of time since the last data recovery point. This objective determines what is considered an acceptable loss of data between the last recovery point and the interruption of service and is defined by the organization.

item.title: 05-01 AWS API
item.description: Rarely do users directly send HTTPS requests directly to the AWS API. Much easier to interact with the API using a variety of Dev Tools.

item.title: 05-02 Amazon Resource Names ARN
item.description: Amazon Resource Names (ARN) uniquely identify AWS resources. ARNs are required to specify a resource unambiguously across all of AWS.

item.title: 05-03 Access Keys
item.description: Access Keys aka AWS Credentials is a ==key and secret== required to have programmatic access to AWS resources when interacting with the AWS API outside of the AWS Management Console.

item.title: 05-04 Infrastructure as Code IaC
item.description: You write a configuration script to automate creating, updating or destroying cloud infrastructure. laC is a blueprint of your infrastructure.

item.title: 06-01 Shared Responsibility Model
item.description: The Shared Responsibility Model is a ==cloud security framework== that defines the security obligations of the customer versa the Cloud Service Provider (CSP) e.

item.title: 06-02 Types of Cloud Computing Responsibility
item.description: On-Premise IaaS PaaS SaaS Applications Applications Applications Applications Data Data Data Data Runtime Runtime Runtime Runtime Middleware Middleware Middleware Middleware OS OS OS OS Virtualization Virtualization Virtualization Virtualization Servers Servers Servers Servers Storage Storage Storage Storage Networking Networking Networking Networking — denotes services managed by you as the user

item.title: 06-04 Shared Responsibility Model - Architecture
item.description: Serverless/Functions - Less Responsibility No more servers, just worry about data and code. Examples. Amplify Serverless Framework Lambda Serverless Architecture Microservices/Containers - More Responsibility Mix and match languages, better utilization of resources

item.title: 07-01 EC2 Overview
item.description: Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) allows you to launch Virtual Machines (VM) #aws-service What is a Virtual Machine? A Virtual Machine (VM) is an emulation of a physical computer using software.

item.title: 07-02 VMs, Containers and Serverless
item.description: Virtual Machines Amazon LightSail #aws-service Amazon LightSail is the ==managed virtual server service.== It is the “friendly” version of EC2 Virtual Machines

item.title: 07-03 High Performance Computing HPC
item.description: The Nitro System The Nitro System A combination of ==dedicated hardware and lightweight hypervisor== enabling faster innovation and enhanced security. All new EC2 instance types use the Nitro System.

item.title: 07-04 Edge and Hybrid Computing Services
item.description: What is Edge Computing When you push your computing workloads outside of your networks to run close to the destination location

item.title: 07-05 Compute Cost and Capacity Management
item.description: Capacity Management - How do we meet the demand of traffic and usages by adding/upgrading servers? EC2 Spot Instances, Reserved Instanced and Savings Plan Ways to save on computing, by paying up in full or partially, by committing to yearly contracts or by being flexible about availability and interruption to the computing service.

item.title: 08-01 Types of Storage Services
item.description: Elastic Block Store (EBS) - Block #aws-service Data is split into evenly split blocks Directly accessed by the OS Supports only a single write volume in short, when you need a virtual hard drive attached to a VM AWS Elastic File System (EFS) - File #aws-service

item.title: 08-02 Introduction to S3
item.description: What is Object Storage (Object -based Storage)? data storage architecture that manages data as objects, as opposed to other storage architectures:

item.title: 08-03 S3 Storage Classes
item.description: AWS offers a range of S3 storage classes that trade Retrieval, Time, Accessibility, and Durability for Cheaper Storage S3 Standard (default) Fast!

item.title: 08-04 AWS Snow Family
item.description: AWS Snow Family are ==storage and compute devices used to physically move data in or out the cloud== when moving data over the internet or private connection to slow, difficult, or costly.

item.title: 08-05 Storage Services
item.description: Simple Storage Service (S3) #aws-service Simple Storage Service (S3) is a ==serverless object storage service.== You can upload very large files and an unlimited amount fo files.

item.title: 09-01 Cloud Networking Services
item.description: Key definitions: Region - the geographical location of your network Availability Zone (AZ) - a data center containing your AWS resources

item.title: 09-02 Enterprise Hybrid Networking Services
item.description: AWS Direct Connect is a private/dedicated connection between your datacenter, office, co-location and AWS. #aws-service ^1d5a3b Direct Connect has two very-fast network connection options:

item.title: 09-03 Security Groups vs NACLs
item.description: Network Access Control Lists (NACLs) #aws-resource Acts as a virtual ==firewall at the subnet level.== You create Allow and Deny Rules.

item.title: 09-04 Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) and Subnets
item.description: Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) is a logically isolated section of the AWS Network where you launch your AWS resources. You choose a range of IPS using CIDR Range

item.title: 1-1 Evolution of Cloud Hosting
item.description: Dedicated Server One physical machine dedicated to a single business. Runs a single web-app/site. Very Expensive, High Maintenance, *High Security

item.title: 1-2 What is a Cloud Service Provider (CSP)?
item.description: A Cloud Service Provider (CSP) is a company which provides Cloud services: which offer many products e.g. tens to hundreds of services that can be chained together to create cloud architectures that are accessible via Single Unified API eg.

item.description: Gartner Magic Quadrant (MQ) is a series of market research reports published by IT consulting firm Gartner that rely on proprietary qualitative data analysis methods to demonstrate market trends, such as direction, maturity, and participants.

item.title: 1-5 Common Cloud Services
item.description: A cloud service can have hundreds of cloud services that are grouped into various types of services. The four most common types for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) would be:

item.title: 1-6 The Evolution of Computing
item.description: Dedicated A physical server wholly utilized by a single customer. Must guess capacity. Overpay for an underutilized service. Can’t vertical scale, need a manual migration.

item.title: 1-7 Types of Cloud Computing
item.description: Software as a Service For Customers A product that is run and managed by the service provider Users don’t worry about how the service is maintained.

item.title: 1-8 Cloud Computing Deployment Models
item.description: Public Cloud Everything (the workload or project) is built on the CSP Aka Cloud-Native or Cloud First Private Cloud Everything built on company’s data centers Also known as On-Premise The cloud could be OpenStack Hybrid Cloud Using both an both an On-Premise and Cloud Service Provider (CSP) Cross Cloud Using Multiple Cloud Providers [!

item.title: 1-9 Deployment Model Use Cases
item.description: Cloud Fully Utilizing Cloud Computing Companies that are starting out today, or are small enough to make the leap from VPS to a CSP.

item.title: 10-01 Data Warehouse
item.description: A relational datastore designed for ==analytic workloads==, which is generally ==column-oriented data-store== Companies will have terabytes and million of rows of data, and they need a fast way to be able to produce analytics reports

item.title: 10-02 Key-Value Database
item.description: A key-value database is a type of non-relational database (NoSQL) that uses a simple key-value method to store data. Key Value Data {species:android, rank:’lt commander'} Worf {species:klingon, rank:’lt commander'} Ro Laren {species:bajoran, affiliation:‘maquis’} Key-values are dumb and fast

item.title: 10-03 Document Database
item.description: A document store is a NoSQL database that stores documents as its primary data structure. A document could be an XML but more commonly is JSON or JSON-Like Document stores are a sub-class of Key/Value stores The components of a document store compared to a Relational database Database (RDBMS) Database (Document) Tables Collection Rows Documents Columns Fields Indexes Indexes Joins Embedding and Linking

item.title: 10-04 NoSQL Database Service
item.description: DynamoDB DynamoDB is a serverless ==NoSQL key/value and document database.== It is designed to scale to billions of records with guaranteed consistent data return in at least a second.

item.title: 10-05 Relational Database Services
item.description: Relational Database Service (RDS) is a ==relational database service== that supports multiple SQL engines. Relational is synonymous with SQL and Online Transactional Processing (OLTP).

item.title: 10-06 Other Database Services
item.description: Redshift #aws-service Redshift is a petabyte-size data-warehouse. Data-warehouses are for Online Analytical Processing (OLAP). Data-warehouses can be expensive because they are keeping data “hot” Meaning that we can run a very complex query and a large amount of data and get that data back very fast ElastiCache #aws-service

item.title: Chapter 1 - What is Cloud Computing
item.description: Question 1 Which of the following six advantages enables small start-up companies to immediately start consuming IT services from public cloud vendors such as AWS?

item.title: Chapter 2 - Introduction to AWS and the Global Infrastructure
item.description: Question 1 Which of the following AWS support plans gives you access to all AWS Trusted Advisor reports? (Select two answers)

item.description: Question 1 Before setting up your billing alarms, which preference setting needs to be enabled first? A. Enable billing alerts B.

item.title: High Performance Computing (HPC)
item.description: The Nitro System The Nitro System A combination of ==dedicated hardware and lightweight hypervisor== enabling faster innovation and enhanced security. All new EC2 instance types use the Nitro System.

item.title: VMs, Containers and Serverless
item.description: Virtual Machines Amazon LightSail #aws-service Amazon LightSail is the ==managed virtual server service.== It is the “friendly” version of EC2 Virtual Machines
